title: Dress and belt with awl case
creator: Wasco, Native American.
description: Plateau cultures thrived in the hilly steppe region between the Cascades in Washington and Oregon and the Rockies in Idaho and Montana. Garments of superior craftsmanship incorporating trade goods, such as this example, expressed personal identity and a familyâ€™s high status. The woman who made this two-hide dress lavishly covered the torso and sleeves with black-and-white beadwork, which she framed with fringes embellished with glass beads, cowry shells, bone, and two highly prized elk canines. The dress is accompanied by its own belt and awl case: awls were among the tools that women used in the preparation of animal skins.
subject: Dresses

title: Pendant with figure
creator: Unknown
description: This is the largest and most elaborately carved standing figure from an understudied culture that flourished in the Pacific Northwest during the first millenium. Its author depicted prominent knees, elbows, and splayed feet as well as a skirt or loincloth, similar to later rbaided grass skirts from the reigon. The figure wears a large headdress--which resembles later known headdresses with earflaps--adorned with alternating bands of sunbursts and triangles and fields of vertical incisions. Although the fiure's function is unknown, the intractate headdress and body marking suggest that it oculd be the portrait of a specific individual.
subject: Wood Carvings

title: Ladle
creator: Chinook Native American
description: Carvers throughout the Northwest Coast made elaborate utensils for ceremonial feasts. This Chinook ladle, with an oval bowl, finely carved rim, and flat handle embellished with two guardian birds, is typical of the Lower Columbia River peoples.
subject: Wood Carvings

title: Bowcase and Quiver
creator: Nez Perce
description: Otter skin, native-tanned leather, wool cloth, glass beads, ermine, and silk ribbon.
subject: Bowcase and Quiver
